questions.text: In conflict, I look for the principle underneath the emotion.
I can hold the line calmly, even when others are reactive.
I take mental notes during arguments so nothing important gets lost.
I can translate tension into a conversation people can survive.
When things get tense, I feel compelled to win—not just resolve.
I’d rather sacrifice my needs than risk being seen as selfish.
If I feel cornered, I attack the rules or authority instead.
I keep my true feelings hidden so I don’t lose power in the room.
I try to fix the problem immediately instead of talking around it.
I notice the unspoken meaning in people’s words and tone.
I sense where conflict is heading before others see it.
I remember patterns—who says what, who avoids what—over time.
I scan for danger in disagreement, even when nothing is happening yet.
When I’m hurt, I become cold instead of expressing it.
I soften my stance quickly to keep the peace, even when I disagree.
